conclusion: The velocity of an object increases while the acceleration is positive, stops increasing once the acceleration becomes zero, and starts decreasing as soon as the acceleration turns negative.
The instant at which the acceleration changes sign (passes through zero) is the instant when the velocity reaches its greatest value.
From t = 0 s to t = 1 s the acceleration is +2 m/s² (positive).
From t = 1 s to t = 2 s the acceleration falls linearly from +2 m/s² to 0; it is still positive throughout this interval.
At t = 2 s the acceleration is exactly zero.
Beyond t = 2 s the acceleration becomes negative (sloping down to –2 m/s²).

premise: The velocity of an object increases while the acceleration is positive, stops increasing once the acceleration becomes zero, and starts decreasing as soon as the acceleration turns negative. At t = 2 s the acceleration is exactly zero.
conclusion: The object’s velocity attains its maximum value at the instant the acceleration first becomes zero.

premise: The object’s velocity attains its maximum value at the instant the acceleration first becomes zero.
conclusion: The velocity is maximum at t = 2 s.
